title: C04-1106

sentences.text: The reality of analogies between words is refuted by noone -LRB- e.g. , I walked is to to walk as I laughed is to to laugh , noted I walked : to walk : : I laughed : to laugh -RRB- .
But computational linguists seem to be quite dubious about analogies between sentences : they would not be enough numerous to be of any use .
We report experiments conducted on a multilingual corpus to estimate the number of analogies among the sentences that it contains .
We give two estimates , a lower one and a higher one .
As an analogy must be valid on the level of form as well as on the level of meaning , we relied on the idea that translation should preserve meaning to test for similar meanings .

summary: The reality of analogies between words is refuted by noone -LRB- e.g. , I walked is to to walk as I laughed is to to laugh , noted I walked : to walk : : I laughed : to laugh -RRB- . But computational linguists seem to be quite dubious about analogies between sentences : they would not be enough numerous to be of any use . We report experiments conducted on a multilingual corpus to estimate the number of analogies among the sentences that it contains . We give two estimates , a lower one and a higher one . As an analogy must be valid on the level of form as well as on the level of meaning , we relied on the idea that translation should preserve meaning to test for similar meanings .

Predicate-is_refuted_by.label: is refuted by
Predicate-is_refuted_by.description: Indicates that a claim or argument made by the subject is contradicted or disproven by the object. The predicate 'is refuted by' establishes a relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the latter provides evidence or reasoning that undermines or invalidates the former's assertion.

Predicate-is_to.label: is to
Predicate-is_to.description: The predicate 'is to' indicates a relationship of equivalence or correspondence between the subject and object. It suggests that the action described by the subject is equivalent to, or has the same meaning as, the verb phrase expressed by the object.

Predicate-seem_to_be_quite_dubious_about.label: seem to be quite dubious about
Predicate-seem_to_be_quite_dubious_about.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a skeptical or uncertain attitude towards the object, suggesting that they are hesitant to accept or endorse it. The phrase 'seem to be quite dubious about' implies a level of doubt or mistrust, implying that the subject is not convinced by the object's validity, relevance, or accuracy.

Predicate-be_dubious_about.label: be dubious about
Predicate-be_dubious_about.description: To express skepticism or uncertainty towards a particular concept, idea, or notion. The subject of this predicate (e.g., computational linguists) questions the validity, relevance, or accuracy of the object (e.g., analogies between sentences), indicating that they are not convinced or persuaded by it.

Predicate-conducted_on_a.label: conducted on a
Predicate-conducted_on_a.description: The predicate 'conducted on a' indicates that an action or process (the subject) was performed using or with reference to something specific (the object), which provides context, support, or foundation for the action. The phrase suggests a connection between the action and the thing it is conducted upon.

Predicate-report.label: report
Predicate-report.description: To convey information or findings about something, typically in a formal or official manner.

Predicate-give.label: give
Predicate-give.description: The predicate 'give' indicates the transfer of possession or control from the subject to the object. It implies a voluntary and intentional action by the subject, resulting in the recipient (object) acquiring something new.

Predicate-refute.label: refute
Predicate-refute.description: To refute means to challenge or contradict a claim, argument, or notion, typically by presenting evidence or logical reasoning that undermines its validity. In this sense, the predicate 'refute' connects the subject (the reality of analogies between words) with the object ('noone') in indicating that there is no basis for supporting or validating the analogy.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is a specific instance or member of a more general category or class denoted by the object. In other words, it establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, where the subject is a narrower concept within the scope of the object.
